examples.text: Can you give a more precise definition of the word?
I can be reasonably precise about the time of the incident.
These estimates will become more precise.
You need to use legally precise terms.
Please give precise details about your previous experience.
We will need a more precise description of the accommodation.

definitions.definition: used to emphasize that something happens at a particular time or in a particular way

examples.text: We were just talking about her when, **at that precise moment**, she walked in.
Doctors found it hard to establish the precise nature of her illness.

definitions.definition: taking care to be exact and accurate, especially about small details

examples.text: We've tried to make the process as precise as possible.

definitions.definition: used to show that you are giving more detailed and accurate information about something you have just mentioned

examples.text: The shelf is about a metre long—well, 98cm, to be precise.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French prescis, from Latin praecis- ‘cut short’, from the verb praecidere, from prae ‘in advance’ + caedere ‘to cut’.
